text: a witness, called for examination, having been first duly sworn, was examined and testified as follows: EXAMINATION

Good afternoon, Dr. Fechter.  We were introduced briefly off the record, but for the record my name is Kelly Kylis and along with Jennifer Alexander I represent the Defendant in the case that we have called you here for today. To begin, would you please state your name and business address.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Sure.  Joel Fechter.  We're at my office in Silver Spring at 10301 Georgia Avenue. We have an office in Bowie as well.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is this Silver Spring office your primary location?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: It's the main office, yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Now, I know you've had your deposition taken before on a number of occasions, but just to make me feel better we'll go through a couple quick ground rules.  The first is that all of your responses must be verbal.  Madam court reporter cannot take down nods of the head or nonverbal responses like uh-huh.  So all of your responses must be yes, no or whatever the answer may be. Secondly, we cannot talk over one another.  I know it's natural in conversation that we anticipate each other's responses, but we have to act like it's a shortwave radio and keep the record clear for madam court reporter.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Great.  If you don't understand any of my questions, please ask me to rephrase them. It's very important that we are on the same page so that the record is clear, and I will not be offended if you tell me I ask a bad question and you don't know what I'm talking about.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Finally, I don't think we'll be here very long, but if you need a break for any reason whatsoever, please let me know and we'll be happy to accommodate you.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Thank you.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: (Deposition Exhibit Number 1 was marked for identification.)

Great.  Now, I will show you what I've marked as Exhibit 1 to your deposition.  This is your subpoena and notice of deposition, essentially your invitation to be here today. Have you seen that before?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: It's probably in my file.  I don't really know that I looked at it.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Well, since you have it in front of you, there is a document schedule attached to it.  I see that you brought a stack of documents with you.  Can you tell me what you've brought today?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I have all of the medical records in her file.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Now, I believe your medical records were provided to me already, so I think we're probably on the same page.  Do you have any kind of transmittal letter that would detail what's in your records?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I don't think so.  I don't think I do, not that I remember seeing.  I have a letter from Mr. Kolker, but I don't think -- it doesn't really detail exactly what records are here.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  I saw that letter and I'm going to go ahead and believe that we have the same stack of records that your office provided.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: It looks like it's about the same height.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: It sure does.  A couple inches, three, four maybe?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Great.  Other than the records that you brought with you, do you have any documents, notes, journals, calendars, anything like that regarding Ms. Vaughn in your care, custody or control?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Other than what's here?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Correct.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: No, I don't think so.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Great.  Now, I have been provided -- I think your office provided me a copy of your CV.  I mean, I also got it from Plaintiff's counsel.  I'm going to mark that as Exhibit 2 to your deposition.  But before I hand that over to you, can you just give me briefly your educational background.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Sure.  I went to University of Maryland in College Park, graduated in 1984.  University of Maryland School of Medicine, graduated in 1988, did an internship and residency at LA County USC Medical Center, which was completed in June of '93, residency in orthopedic surgery, and then an orthopedic sports medicine fellowship at the Kerlan-Jobe Orthopedic Clinic in Inglewood, California, completed in July of '94.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Excellent.  I know you are board certified; is that right?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I am.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: In what specialty are you board certified?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Orthopedic surgery.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what entity is it that governs that certification?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: The American Board of Orthopedic Surgeons.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And are you current in your certification?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I am.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you have to recertify?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I do unfortunately.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When is your next recertification?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I last recertified in 2015, so I guess that means my next one would be in about 10 years.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You can go a little earlier, but that's the period of certification through 2025.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Understood.  Do you hold any state licenses?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Actually maybe through 2026, I'm sorry. I have a license to practice medicine in Maryland and California.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How often do you practice in California, if at all?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I don't anymore.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  When did you get that license?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: In my training, which was out in California.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is that something that you have to keep current?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: It's the same requirements basically as a Maryland license.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So you do keep it current?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Oh, yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you maintain privileges at any hospitals?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Yes.  I have privileges at Holy Cross Hospital, Shady Grove Adventist and Suburban Hospital.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: (Deposition Exhibit Number 2 was marked for identification.)
All right.  I have marked your CV as Exhibit 2 to your deposition.  I can hand it to you.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Now, you are currently employed here in this office, which is the office of Drs. Mininberg & Fechter, M.D., correct?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: That's true.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And you are a partner of this practice?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I am.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Am I using the correct terminology there?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I'm a partner, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And how long have you worked in this practice?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I came here in '96 and I've been here since then.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Where did you work before that?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: The Columbia Medical Plan at the Patuxent Medical Group in Columbia, Maryland.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How long did you work there?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Not quite two years.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what was your job title or position?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Orthopedic surgeon.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you work anywhere else since your residency?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Well, I did my fellowship and then after I was done training I went to Columbia where we did the job I was just talking about, and then I came here.  So post-education I've had two jobs.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Very nice.  Do you maintain any other positions currently at any -- in any capacity?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: What do you mean?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you like maintain any positions in teaching or any -- do you work part-time at any practices?  I'm being very broad.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: No.  I work here.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you have any publications?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Yes.  They're listed in my CV.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Yes.  Of those listed in your CV -- I did not read them, I confess -- are any of those publications related to the injuries claimed by Ms. Vaughn in this case?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Not really.  They're mostly shoulder and knee kind of things.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Before I forget, the CV that you have in front of you that I've marked as Deposition Exhibit 2, is that up to date?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: It looks like it.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Are there any changes or is there anything new that you have to add to this CV?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I don't think so.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Great.  Now, Doctor, tell me about your current practice.  Do you -- in addition to seeing patients -- well, let me back up.  I assume in your practice you see patients.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: That's right.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you also have administrative duties?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Not really.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  When you say not really, I mean, you are a partner in the practice.  Is there any -- you must do some administrative things or --
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: So what do you mean by administrative things?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: That's an excellent point.  Not clinical work.  Time spent not seeing patients.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I mean, when I'm not seeing patients, I sometimes am dictating.  I mean, we have an office manager who runs the office.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Understood.  Okay.  So would you say that your practice is 100 percent clinical?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I think I would.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  I'm sure many doctors would be envious. Do you do any teaching in addition to your clinical practice?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Not really.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Any research?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Not anymore.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When was last time you did research or a research project?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I mean, I haven't done it since I finished my training really.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Now, as an orthopedic surgeon, what type of procedures, surgical procedures, do you perform?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Most of my surgeries are to the shoulder and knee.  I do some other stuff on a less frequent basis, some surgeries involving wrists, elbows, but, I mean, I would say the majority are knee and shoulder cases.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Now, I've noticed -- very briefly, I've noticed that there are a lot of doctors who focus on the knee and shoulder together, and those aren't necessarily body parts that you would think go together.  Is there some reason why those two things tend to be?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: They're two parts of the body that are commonly treated arthroscopically.  So a lot of people who have some extra training in arthroscopy or a particular interest in arthroscopy end up focusing on those joints because they're some of the more common joints in the body that end up getting arthroscopic treatment.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: That makes perfect sense.  Thank you, Doctor.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Sure.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Could you tell me, if you could estimate, what percentage of your practice is -- or what percentage of the patients you see come to you for shoulder and knee treatment as compared to other body parts?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: You know, it's pretty common.  I would say certainly every day I see people with knee and shoulder problems.  I don't know beyond telling you it's a frequent complaint how to answer that.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Now, we are obviously here for a lawsuit, so I know that you do some medical-legal consulting work.  Can you tell me how often you do medical-legal work?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: So I don't really keep a tally or a count, but I have estimated in the past that in terms of what I do seeing patients maybe 10, 15 percent, somewhere in that neighborhood is -- would be evaluations for things like this, and the balance would be treatment of patients who have been injured.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So about 10 or 15 percent of your patients are here for things like IMEs?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: That's what I would estimate.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  I'm just making sure we're on the same page.  And have you been -- you have obviously been retained as an expert in this case.  You've been retained as an expert in prior cases, correct?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I have.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Could you tell me -- well, let me back up.  You've been retained in this case by the Plaintiff.  Is all of your practice, your medical-legal consulting practice for plaintiffs or do you also do defense work?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I also do defense work.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Can you give me an estimate as to what percentage of your medical-legal work is for plaintiffs versus defendants?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: The significant majority is for plaintiffs or claimants.  I mean, I've estimated in the past, and again I don't have a count, so it's just an estimation, you know, 5, 10, 12 percent defense and the balance would be plaintiffs or claimants.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you remember when your last defense case was?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: The last defense evaluation that I did?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Sure.  The last time you were retained and did some medical-legal work for -- on behalf of the defendant.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Probably a couple weeks ago.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Have you ever been qualified as an expert in court?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When was the last time you were qualified as an expert in court?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Do you mean -- I'm sorry, do you mean testifying in court or a deposition?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Yes, I'm sorry.  I should have clarified that.  You have testified in court, have you not?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: On occasion.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And when you testified in court were you qualified as an expert by the judge?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When was the last time?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I probably haven't been to court for, I'm going to guess a year, 10 months, 11 months, 12 months, something like that.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What court was it, if you remember?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I believe it was Prince George's County Circuit Court.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Were you testifying on behalf of the defendant or the plaintiff?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Plaintiff.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What kind of case was it, if you remember?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: It was -- I think it was a car accident case.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you testify strictly as an expert or as a treating physician?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I don't remember.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay, Doctor.  What, if anything, did you do to prepare for your deposition today?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I reviewed this pile of medical records, went through it a couple of times.  I did that yesterday.  And then when I was waiting for you guys to come, I kind of looked over things again and read my reports again and glanced through the records.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Great.  Did you speak with Plaintiff's counsel, Mr. Kolker, who is here with us today about your deposition before today?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I did speak to him.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When was that?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Yesterday.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what did you talk about?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: My opinions in this case.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what about your opinions did you discuss?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: What's in my report really.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Did you speak with anyone else in preparation for your deposition today?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Have you reviewed any discovery in this case?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I don't think so.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Have you been provided with Ms. Vaughn's deposition transcript?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: So to be honest with you, I can't tell you if it's in here somewhere.  But if it is, I wouldn't have paid too much attention to it.  I didn't read it if it's there.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I don't think I have it.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I don't think you have it either if my stack is the same as yours. Now, your records of Ms. Vaughn include other treating providers' records, correct?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And where did you get those records?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: They would have been sent by Mr. Kolker.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Now, there are two, I believe, transmittal letters from Mr. Kolker to you referencing the records that he has sent you. If we were to look back at those transmittal letters, would the dates be correct as to when you received those records?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I don't know.  I don't know when we received them.  I mean, I would assume we received them shortly after the dates on the letters.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Right.  Okay.  So you've had them some time.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Yeah, I think so.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Now, in addition to the records themselves, what I'm going to refer to as records, which would be records of the actual treatment and the doctors' notes and things like that, did you also review any medical bills or charges?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Not that I remember.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Have you spoken to any of Ms. Vaughn's other doctors or treatment providers?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you have any handwritten notes about this case?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Are they included in --
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: They should be, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you recall when you were first contacted about this particular case?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: No.  I guess it would have been around the time that that letter arrived.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Do you remember how you were first contacted, whether it was by letter or by phone?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I think it was by letter.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Have you been asked to come to trial in this case?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Not that I know of.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: (Deposition Exhibit Number 3 was marked for identification.)
Doctor, I will show you what I'm going to mark now as Deposition Exhibit 3.  This is your -- or this is the Plaintiff's Expert Witness Statement, and you will see your name there on that first page.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Have you seen this before?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Have you spoken to Mr. Kolker about this expert witness statement?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Not that I recall.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you know if you provided any input in any way in drafting that statement?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I don't remember talking about it. Perhaps it came from my report, but I didn't talk about it.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Are you keeping them all over there?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: That's what I was doing.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Moving on, I would like to direct your attention to your evaluation of Ms. Vaughn on March 19th of 2019, earlier this year.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I see you have your report.  That's fantastic.  I'm also going to mark a copy of that report as Deposition Exhibit 4 for when I need it.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: (Deposition Exhibit Number 4 was marked for identification.)
Now, Doctor, on March 19, 2019, in what capacity did you treat Ms. Vaughn?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I didn't treat her.  I evaluated her.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What is the difference?  If you could --
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Sure.  So this was an evaluation. Treatment is different.  Treatment we're all familiar with.  The patient goes into the doctor.  You have a problem.  You want to figure out what the problem is generally and you want to get it treated to feel better. An evaluation is a visit where the patient comes in generally sent by an interested party, an attorney, an insurance company, and you're not treating the patient trying to make them better, but you're evaluating them, talking to them in order to answer questions about a case typically or an injury.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So in performing an evaluation where you're not treating the patient, how do you arrive at your evaluation?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Well, you review the records, talk to the patient, get a history, do a physical examination, review the imaging studies and then you using your experience, knowledge and the information that you've gleaned, you come up with an opinion.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Great.  Now, do you have an independent recollection of the visit with Ms. Vaughn in March of 2019?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Not much.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What do you remember, if anything?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I really -- I'm going to rely on my medical records for answering your questions.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Oh, understood.  I was just wondering if there's -- if you remember anything about her in particular.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Not particularly.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Now, when you saw her on March 19, 2019, the date of the accident that you were evaluating her for was June 11, 2015, correct?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So in March of '19 you were almost four years post-accident, right?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Approaching that, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Yeah, not quite four years.  So before you saw her on March 19th, you received the records that we've talked about, correct?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And you reviewed those records before seeing her?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: So I kind of glanced through them as I go in.  I don't usually review all the medical records before the patient comes in because sometimes they don't come in.  So I review them a bit as I'm getting ready to go see the patient, and then I go see the patient, I talk to the patient and I'm kind of glancing through the medical records as we talk and discuss the case.  And then afterwards, I make sure I thoroughly review all of the records.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So at the time that you see the patient, do you get a history from the patient?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And so during your evaluation, I know you're glancing at the records, but are you also relying on the patient's verbal history?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Very much so.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And when generally do you review records after having seen the patient?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: As soon as I can after I see the patient.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Now, in this case before you -- or when you saw Ms. Vaughn on March 19, 2019 when you reviewed her records, do you recall reviewing records that predated her date of accident of June 11, 2015?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So at the time that you saw her or when you reviewed those records, you were aware that she was already undergoing physical therapy treatments?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I was aware that she had a previous injury that had been treated and was in the course of being treated.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And when you say in the course of being treated, is it fair for me to characterize that as ongoing?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I think that's fair.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Now, when you reviewed those records, did you pay any attention to her complaints of pain in particular?  And forgive me, I didn't word that terribly well.  When you were reviewing the records that predated her June 11, 2015 incident, did you pay any particular attention to her pain ratings that she had provided to her doctors based on their notes?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I mean, I read the notes.  I tried to take everything into account.  I don't remember specifically what her pain number ratings were.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: But is that something that you would pay attention to when you're reviewing them?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I mean, I try to pay attention to everything that's pertinent, and I think that's pertinent.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So based upon your review of Ms. Vaughn's records that predated the June 11, 2015 incident, are you familiar with her prior diagnoses of chronic pain and previous surgeries and other medical procedures?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I am.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  I'd like to just go through some of those with you quickly.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Now, you're familiar with her prior diagnosis of a musculoskeletal disorder, right?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: What do you mean by a musculoskeletal disorder?  That's kind of a big, all-encompassing term.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I was hoping to ask you to explain that one to me.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Well, you'll have to show me where it was and I'll try to.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I don't know that I can.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Because that can mean a lot of different things.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Well, what can it mean?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I would say it could mean almost any orthopedic problem.  I mean, a musculoskeletal disorder is pretty nonspecific.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Well, let me back up.  Based on your review of Ms. Vaughn's records that predate the incident, you are aware that she was experiencing what I'd like to call as chronic pain issues?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: That's true.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And those chronic pain issues that she was experiencing prior to June 11, 2015 were pretty much throughout her body, correct?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: So it looked to me like in the period of time most immediately before this injury, her complaints were largely related to neck, shoulder, upper back sort of areas.  Now, she told me that she did have problems with her low back that she was still having.  So I know that that's true, but she told me that they became dramatically worse after this injury. So although the notes don't really reflect a lot of treatment directed specifically at her low back, I know she was having some pain in the low back because she told me that.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Are you familiar with her prior -- with her diagnosis of like spinal stenosis or facet disease, and please correct me if I'm conflating diagnoses, that predated the June 11, 2015 incident?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Well, she definitely had some degenerative changes in her low back that predated this injury, and the things you're mentioning are degenerative.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So spinal stenosis and facet disease, are they one and the same or are those two different?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: So interesting.  So stenosis refers to a narrowing of the space available for either the cord, the spinal canal or the nerve roots. Okay.  And facet joint disease can help to produce that stenosis.  So stenosis is just the narrowing and that can be contributed to by many things, including facet degenerative changes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Thank you.  I will use the correct pronunciation. Now, along with those diagnoses, are you familiar with her prior complaints of diagnosis of neuropathy related thereto?

We know she didn't have a completely normal lumbar spine before that and I thought that sort of quick jerking trying to save yourself movement when your leg slips out in front of you could certainly cause a low back problem.

text: Okay.  Thank you.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Sure.

text: Well, it's in my report right here.

text: Oh, okay.  So if you could explain -- we're about what, seven, eight lines down?

text: It was at L4-5, yes, and then there was a bulge at L3-4.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Now, Doctor, if I could direct your attention down a few more lines where you're talking about an MRI obtained on 10/22/16, which was then compared to her prior scans.  It says that one revealed the interval development of disc herniation at L3-4.

text: Yes.

speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Sure.  So in the first MRI scan from 6/18/15 at L3-4, there was -- the radiologist said moderate left foraminal narrowing due to a disc bulge.  So there was some bulging there, but not something that the radiologist called a frank disk herniation. When that scan that you were just talking about on 10/22/16 was done, they felt that there was actually -- the radiologist who read it felt that there had developed a disc herniation on the left side at L3-4, whereas the prior MRI scan had shown a bulge at that level.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Thank you, Doctor.  So is it fair to say that this problem starts out as a bulge and can, if it gets worse, become a herniation?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: It can.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: That's the progression of the disease, the complaints or the -- I'm not sure what word I'm looking for here.  Please forgive me.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Let me help you.  So a disc bulge doesn't have to become a frank disc herniation. They don't always, but they can.  Like you just said, they can progress and it can become a herniation.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And based on the review of these MRIs, it looks like that's what happened to Ms. Vaughn?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I think so.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Now, how does a disc bulge become a herniation?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: So through wear and tear, walking around, activities of daily living can put stress on the discs and that can cause the bulge to progress.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Now, about -- I'll take you just a couple more lines down when you reviewed her updated MRI from July 21, 2017.

text: Okay.

text: Yes.

speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: So I'm not sure that it's actually very different.  So one of the things you have to be aware of is that different people can look at the same MRI scans and you can get different readings.  Okay.  It's an interpretation thing and not everyone interprets the findings on an MRI scan in exactly the same way. So it's hard sometimes to compare findings based on reports.  Sometimes it's easier.  Like this, we're talking about a disc herniation and before we were talking about a disc bulge.  I think that's significant.  But, I mean, I think the bottom line is she definitely has some degenerative changes and she has, again, the left L3-4 disc herniation and protrusion and now they're describing it actually as an extrusion.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what is that?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: So an extrusion is where the piece of disc actually breaks off from the main disc and it's extruded.  It's separate.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Thank you, Doctor.  Now, the July 21, 2017 MRI was right before she had her surgery with Dr. Schreiber on August 31, 2017, right?

text: Yes.

text: So was that surgery to -- well, tell me what that surgery was for.

text: So in that surgery Dr. Schreiber addressed the two levels of concern, that being the L4-5 level and the L3-4 level, that we were just talking about.  So he decompressed basically the areas where it looked like there was some narrowing and compromise of the neurologic structures with that surgery.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So did he repair the extrusion or is that unrelated?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: He removed it.  That's what the discectomy is.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I see.  So the discectomy is removing the one that had come out of place, what we call the extrusion.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Yes, it's removing the herniated disc.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Understood.  And the laminectomy is creating space?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: The laminectomy is removing the lamina, which is the bony part of the back of the spine. So to get down to this area, you have to take off some of the ligaments and then you have to either remove a part of the lamina, which is called the laminotomy, or you can remove the whole lamina if you need to get a really wide exposure, which is called the laminectomy, and just allows access to the area where you need to do your work.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And what work?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: So he did -- he removed the L4 lamina. He did foraminotomies at L5 on both sides, which means that he opened up the space in the neural foramina for the nerve roots.  He did L4 foraminotomies and then he did the partial laminectomy at L3 and the discectomy where he removed the disc.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Thank you.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Sure.
speaker: THE WITNESS

The person is not a hundred percent, in this case with regard to her low back.  And then there's a related concept of disability, which is not really the medical determination which refers to how an impairment affects a person's life, activities of daily living, the ability to earn a living, you know, things like that.

text: Well, so, yes, yes, I do, but it seemed to me that you didn't really make any opinions in here about the low back, so I was hoping you could tell me what conclusions you did find about the low back in this report.

text: Well, I said I was unable to causally relate her ongoing back pain or the need for her low back surgery to this injury from 7/20/14.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you remember why that was?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Yeah.  I mean, she commented on and complained of some low back pain initially for, I thought, a relatively short period of time and then there's not much mention of it, and so there was a pretty long time when she wasn't complaining about it and then it came up again after this other injury that we're talking about.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Now, when you saw her on February 16, 2018, you had her medical records beforehand or at the time of your evaluation to review, correct?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And I think we already went through just a couple of times that she -- well, you agreed with me earlier that she had been complaining about low back pain earlier in 2015, right?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I believe so.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So that was after the July 20, 2014 incident at Rose's, but before the Walmart incident, correct?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Yeah.  You know, I'm not sure if it was 2015 or two-thousand -- most of them with regard to her neck were in 2014 I believe.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Well, if her records did show that she was complaining of pain in her low back in early 2015, so after the incident at Rose's but before Walmart, would that change your opinion as to whether the low back pain at that time was causally related to the incident at Rose's?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I don't think so because I already knew she had a long history of ongoing back pain.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Before the incident at Rose's?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Before the incident at Rose's, I think you told me she had had pain in her back for 20 years.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I think it was pain management for 20 years, but, yes, I think that's fair to say.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I mean, she told me she had, you know, a long history with regard to her back.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And when you saw her in February of 2018, were you also aware of the Walmart incident that she's complaining about?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Yes.  I don't know that I knew it was in Walmart, but I had talked about the episode that she had.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Did that factor into your evaluation of her based on the low back complaints that she was still treating for when you saw her in 2018?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I think so.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How did that factor in?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Well, it seemed like a much more reasonable explanation for her ongoing low back pain than the fall in Rose's.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: But the fall in Rose's, she was seated in a chair, correct?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And fell down striking the floor, correct?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: She fell back, yeah, from the chair that broke she said.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So if she fell backwards, inevitably she landed on her back and/or shoulder, correct?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I mean, I don't know what she landed on.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Right.  But if she fell backwards, there's -- I mean, the law of physics means that she had to have fallen onto her backside in some way, correct?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Maybe.  I don't know how she fell. Sometimes people fall forwards.  I don't know how she fell.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Well, either way she did make -- she fell onto the floor, so she made impact with the floor.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I believe so.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And why is it your opinion, if it is your opinion, that falling and landing on the floor is not as consistent with the low back pain as a slip in which you do not fall?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Well, it is consistent with low back pain and she had low back pain, and then it was -- she was treated, but her treatment notes reflect treatment in the vast predominance for her neck and shoulder.  And if you look at the notes from the Multi-Specialty, they're really talking about her cervical/thoracic spine, neck/upper back and they're really not talking about her low back.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Now, looking back at the records -- well, I'm sorry, let me start that one again.  You reviewed records obviously after her incident at Walmart, too, correct?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And that included a lot of physical therapy treatment records, correct?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And in those records, if I may characterize the bulk of them, reference treatments to both her shoulder, which I believe in your report that we've marked as Exhibit 5, you causally relate to the incident at Rose's and her low back pain.  Isn't that -- is that right, is that fair to say?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: There's a lot of notes that reflect treatment to both, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And so based on your two reports, if I could combine them for just a second, it seems to me that your opinion -- and tell me if I'm wrong, your opinion is that her shoulder issues are all attributable to the incident at Rose's, and the low back is attributable to -- with the exception of the underlying chronic pain that she had before, attributable to the Walmart incident.  Is that fair to say?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Well, the shoulder I also think was related to some preexisting problems.  But of these injuries we're talking about, I would relate that to the one from 2014.  And the ongoing low back issues, I would relate to the incident at Walmart.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Understood.  So given that and given that her physical therapy treatments were for both of those body parts, do you have an opinion as to how -- well, let me start that over.  Is there a way for you to parse out what of that treatment is related to the Walmart incident versus the incident at Rose's or her underlying degenerative conditions?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Well, I would say that the treatment to the low back, I would relate to the Walmart incident and the treatment to her shoulder I would relate to the Rose's problem.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And is there -- can you tell me how you would apportion that, if you could, based on your review of the records?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I don't really know how I would apportion it beyond saying that a portion of it is related to this other injury and a portion of it is related to this Walmart problem.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is there any way for you to quantify that, like 50/50, 30/70?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I mean, I suppose it would depend on how much time, effort and service was done to each of those body parts in each individual therapy session, which probably would be pretty hard to figure out.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  I haven't been able to figure it out, so.  But I am not nearly as smart as you are, Doctor, so --
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I'm not sure about that.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Don't sell yourself short.
speaker: MR. KOLKER

text: All right.  Let me get myself back on track here.  Okay.  So we've talked about your visits with Ms. Vaughn on March 19, 2019 and February 16, 2018.  Do you recall any other visits with Ms. Vaughn for any reason?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: So, again, I'm relying on my records. I don't see any other visits in my notes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Have you spoken with Ms. Vaughn since March 2019?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Not that I recall.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: (Deposition Exhibit Number 6 was marked for identification.)

Okay, Doctor.  Let me mark as Deposition Exhibit 6 this -- I'll represent to you this is the report authored by Dr. -- I think it's Mark Rosenthal, I should know that, Mark Rosenthal about Ms. Vaughn in this case. Have you seen that before?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Would you like to take just a moment to read it?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Thank you, Doctor.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Sure.  Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Thank you, Doctor.  Now, do you know Dr. Rosenthal, either personally or professionally?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I mean, I've seen his name on reports before.  I don't know him.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Never met him?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I don't think so.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Now, as you just read, Dr. Rosenthal has done a records review in this case and has provided his opinions in this report, and one of those opinions is that her complaints and physical findings are the same after the event as they were before the event, and that's based on his review of the records that he puts forth in his report.  Do you agree with that assessment?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Why not?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Because of what she told me about her pain and how she reacted and how her pain changed after the injury.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And can you describe that for me, please, like what about it.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Sure.  She told me that her pain was dramatically increased by this slip and that it remained at a significantly elevated level throughout her treatment.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So is it fair to say that your assessment on that point is simply based on her subjective complaints as opposed to any specific findings in the records?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Sure.  I mean, it's based on her history that she gave me and I'm taking her at her word.  If her history was different, I could have a completely different conclusion.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Understood.  What I'm going to refer to as the second part here of Dr. Rosenthal's opinions is that she had a new onset of symptoms -- this is in the third paragraph from the bottom -- in 2017 and that's what led to the surgery that she had in 2018.  Do you agree with that assessment?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: So let me just point out something that I noticed which is that, you know, Dr. Rosenthal doesn't appear to have had all the medical records when he did this review.  He says she does eventually have an MRI of the lumbar spine July 21, 2017. There were two MRI scans before that he doesn't seem to be aware of having been done, and I don't know that that might not have changed some of his conclusions.  I don't know because I'm not him, but to know that there was an MRI done, you know, in the neighborhood of a week or so after this injury and that there was another MRI done in 2016 and that this MRI that he's talking about was far from the first MRI of her low back since this incident occurred, so the bottom line is I disagree.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Well, since you mentioned the prior MRIs, it is true, isn't it, that those MRIs showed different levels, I think is how you characterized of problems in her spine, correct?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Well, they showed different degrees of problems at a couple of different levels of her spine.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And so if -- is it fair for me to say that the degree of problem in 2017 was worse than in 2015?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So then is it also fair to say that if it's worse two years later, it could be characterized as a new onset of symptoms?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: No.  To me worse is not new.  Worse is an increasing level of symptoms.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And explain to me why it would get worse.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Well, if her changes in her lumbar spine got worse, she had a disc extrusion -- well, she had a protrusion, then she had an extrusion.  That certainly is consistent I think with a worsening.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what generally causes that, those worsening stages this quick?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: The worsening of -- I'm not sure what you mean.  The worsening of symptoms, the worsening of the MRI findings?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: The changes that I believe we see on the MRI.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: So I think we talked about that. That's -- you know, you can have changes like that if there's a problem with the disc, degenerative or injury to a disc, with time, with wear and tear.  Although it doesn't always happen, that can progress, can worsen and can develop into a herniation.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Understood.  So if we see a progression here in her MRI findings that you've reviewed from the 2015, 2016, 2017, that progression is it fair to say that that is related to the degenerative wear and tear kind of life changes as opposed to a traumatic injury?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: It could be, and this is where you have to go to the history, talk to the patient about how she was doing, what sorts of changes she experienced in her symptoms relative to the timing of these injuries.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Thank you, Doctor.  Let me just run through your opinions real quick and then I think we'll be all set here.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So if you are subpoenaed to appear at trial, will you be offering an opinion to a reasonable degree of medical certainty as to what caused Ms. Vaughn's alleged injuries?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I think so.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what is that opinion?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: It's the opinion that she had an underlying degenerative condition and that this fall aggravated that condition and contributed to her ultimate need for surgery.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what is the foundation for that opinion?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I mean, I think that's what we've been talking about the whole time.  The foundation is the fact that she had some preexisting problems and some preexisting pain and some preexisting changes on MRI scans, and she had this slip in the Walmart and developed significantly increased pain at that time.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Thank you, Doctor.  Now, if subpoenaed to appear at trial, do you intend to offer any opinions to a reasonable degree of medical certainty or probability as to her damages?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: What do you mean?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Well, you told me earlier you hadn't reviewed any medical bills.  Do you intend to offer any opinions related thereto?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I mean, I could have opinions if I reviewed the medical records and bills, but I don't think -- I haven't so far.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Do you intend to offer any opinion if subpoenaed to appear at trial as to Ms. Vaughn's pain and suffering?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I mean, I can talk about the problems that she had that she talked to me about and the symptoms that she has and the activities in her life that are affected.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And what would that opinion be?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Well, she told me that -- so she told me that she had intermittent and dull, sometimes sharp pain in her low back.  It ranged from a 3 to 7 over 10 level of intensity.  That's a scale I ask them about where zero is no pain at all, 10 is the worse pain they could ever imagine. Pain radiating into both lower extremities, more marked on the right side than the left, numbness, tingling and weakness in both legs, more pain with prolonged sitting, standing, walking.  Attempted jogging, repetitive bending, stooping and lifting, she had problems with stiffness and weakness. Pushing, pulling, twisting activities bothered her back, and I think that's mostly the functional kind of stuff that we talked about.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Great.  Thank you.  Well, one thing we did not talk about if subpoenaed to appear at trial, do you intend to offer any opinions as to the need for future treatment that you would relate to the Walmart incident?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: So I didn't say anything about that, but my recommendation would be home exercise, stretching, strengthening, core strengthening program.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So then if you would recommend a home exercise program, is it fair to say that you would not offer any opinions at trial as to future medical costs?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: That's fair to say.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Now, I noted in your report I believe you noted that she, Ms. Vaughn, was not working at the time you saw her, correct?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: No.  So she told me she was unemployed at the time of the injury.  When I saw her, she told me she was working at customer service.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Forgive me, I meant to say at the time of the incident.  So -- and then she was working.  Okay.  So if subpoenaed to appear at trial, do you intend to offer any opinions as to whether Ms. Vaughn had to miss any time from work as related to this injury?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: No.  She was unemployed, so I don't really think about time missed from work because she wasn't working at the time.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Very good.  Doctor, have we talked about all of the opinions that you would offer at trial if subpoenaed to testify in this case?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: I mean, I don't know.  If you ask me another question, I might have a different opinion.  I mean, I think these are most of them that we're talking about.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Excellent.  I believe those are all of my questions.
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Mr. Kolker, do you have any?
speaker: MS. KYLIS

text: Just a couple things. EXAMINATION

text: Yes.

text: I don't have any other questions.
speaker: MR. KOLKER

text: I'm good, too. Thank you, Dr. Fechter. You have the right to review or you can waive -- based on your nonverbal wave there, I'm going to state for the record that you're going to waive reading and signing.
